ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: If you want to learn about experimental design, causal inference, or how to become an R wiz (or at least try) then this is the class for you. I gained such a deep appreciation for experimental design and it changed the way I think about the way the world works. This is one of those rare Yale classes that you will actually take away something of practical, real world use.
I learned about randomized experiments and how to design/conduct/analyze different types of experiments that are often used in political science research.
Experimental design, coding and how to think about statistical results.
The fundamentals of causal inference (average treatment effect, difference-in-means estimation, potential outcomes framework), compliance, heterogeneous treatment effects
I learned the theoretical and statistical background behind randomized experiments and also gained a deeper appreciation for experimentation as a whole in approaching social sciences.
This was a great course in learning how randomized experiments work, why they are needed and how to conduct them. The course was very interesting, and the final project was fulfilling!

I learned about the usefulness of randomized experiments to answer causal questions, the mechanics of estimation of treatment effects, how to perform randomization inference, how to analyze experimental designs, using covariates and ordinary least squares to estimate effects, interaction effects in experiments, and one-sided noncompliance in experiments.
Casual inference, how to design randomized experiments, R
Looked at data studies in political science and learned how to replicate them
Causal inference, research design and critical thinking.
I learned how to code in R, and became especially skilled in tidyverse.
I have gained needed knowledge about the logic of experiments

I learned about how randomization in experiments can allow us to draw useful insights and conclusions about the effects that treatments have on outcomes. I learned useful frameworks of both interpreting and designing experiments which will allow for easily reproducible and understandable results. I also learned a good deal about R, especially working with packages included in tidyverse and DeclareDesign (a random experiment-focused packaged co-written by prof coppock!), and some good practices in making my code neater. I learned about different issues that you may run into during a randomized experiment (e.g. compliance issues), and how you may overcome them or work around them to still get meaningful results from your data.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Alex is the strength of this course. Of course, he is a genius when it comes to experimental design, but he does what every teacher should aspire to-- to inspire his students to think deeply about the way the world works. No weaknesses to note.

This course facilitated student learning and participation, and Professor Coppock and Shikhar were an amazing instructor/TA duo who made sure that students were understanding and engaging with the course material.

Really great course, good pace of learning, right amount of work assigned. However, I think office hours with the TA could be greatly improved. 10 minute slots are just not enough, and I don't get as much out of office hours when it's one on one. I think people appreciate one-on-one office hours with professors, but certainly not with the TA. Office hours with a TA should be collaborative and open to all. We should not need to make an appointment and only get a 10-minute time slot. Office hours are also supposed to be a chance for students to hear each other's questions and learn from those questions.

Great class, great lectures, great materials and feedback. 

Nothing to improve.
A very comprehensive course with useful sections and intuitive psets!

I don't think there were any weaknesses to this course. I truly learned a lot from the lectures, and I liked how one class of the week was typically dedicated to learning the topic while the other class was dedicated to discussing a relevant social science article that used experimentation techniques.
Great course, very helpful professor and TA!

Strengths: Coppock is so, so good. Hes enthusiastic about the material and knows his stuff. I also appreciated the in-class discussion of published papers! The homework and exams were very fair.

Weaknesses: I could have used more guidance on the expectations for the final project.

This class was amazing! I really learned a lot. Alex is great at teaching and presenting material in a clear and concise manner. His way of teaching really facilitates learning. The TF was amazing too and all the sections were very helpful. Our textbook was great and all the parts were manageable. I liked the final project and how we got to use what we learned on the project.
I thought this was an overall engaging course. I just hated tidyverse
Everything about this course is perfect!!! I love the weekly discussion of papers! I also become more interested in political science because of this course!

The greatest strength of this course is Shikhar the TF and the flexibility of the final project. I was able to conduct a practice experiment on a hobby I love and post to social media as part of the experiment. The greatest weakness of the course is the timeliness in which assignments and feedback were received, though this was due to only having one TF.
This was a great course! Very well-suited for and focused on student learning. The only drawback I noted was that at times, I felt like some of the statistics concepts weren't well explained.

Strengths: Professor Coppock is truly excited about what he teaches, so if you look over the syllabus and are interested in the content you will have a great time in this course. 
Weaknesses: I wish the lecture content was recorded so that I could rewatch the content or listen at my own pace.

Strengths: Prof Coppock was so well versed in what he taught (he is even writing a textbook related to the course!), so I always felt energized by his lectures and that everything we covered was actually useful and applicable. Also, our TF was awesome!

Weaknesses: The psets can be a bit technically challenging, especially if you haven't coded or worked with R before. Luckily, Shikhar had great sections that would help guide us through useful coding frameworks. Also, the classes were sometimes rushed.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you are interested in these topics you will benefit enormously from a semester in this course. It is accessible to everyone as long as you have some statistical "sense" and a willingness to play with R for hours at a time.

Yes! It was very eye-opening to learn about how political science experiments are designed and conducted in order to test theories and hypothesis about a wide variety of phenomena in the social world.
Yes, if you want to learn about experiments.

Yes! If you have a stats background, the coding portion of the class should be no problem. The poli-sci applications of the stats is very interesting, and you get to read several important papers in the poli-sci literature from the past couple of years.
YES. Experiments may not sound like the most intriguing topic, but I truly looked forward to every single class because of how interesting the topics were and how well they were taught.

Yes - Prof. Coppock is a wonderful professor, and he organizes and teaches very well. He is also very understanding and will help you if you are a bit behind on understanding R or any of the concepts. Really strengthened my comfort with working with R, my statistics knowledge, and understanding of econ research and how research is conducted. Really great class for those interested in writing thesis or doing graduate research in the future.
Yes! You get a good mix of political science and statistics. Will recommend as a great social science class for stem majors too.

Yes!! You learn so much in a really supportive class. Its not too high workload, but you come away really getting the concepts and being able to understand and critically evaluate papers on field experiments. Its also really cool to see what questions you can answer with experiments!
DEFINITELY!! One of the best classes Ive taken at Yale. I took it for an S&DS elective and it was really helpful and not too much work.
Yes. Its a great introduction course and gives you hands on experience
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. It is very informative and a great way to learn about field experiments.
Yes!!! One of the best courses I have taken at Yale!

I would recommend this course to another student looking to understand the theory and practice behind running fair and randomized experiments. This course is a fair amount of work, but it is all very doable and enjoyable.
Yes! This is a very interesting, fun, and engaging course.
If you are interested in data science for the social sciences / field experiments yes
yes
